### **Chapter 1: The Sky-Mirage**

The coral was a knife-edge under Taori’s bare feet, a sun-bleached spine separating two worlds.

Behind him, the vast, untamed Pacific crashed against the outer reef, a constant thunder that sent a mist of salt and foam hissing into the wind. Before him, the lagoon of Karolin lay like a sheet of impossible turquoise, an ocean in miniature, placid and shimmering under the sun. It was forty miles of captive sea, and as of yesterday, it was his.

Everything was his. The shouts of the children chasing crabs along the white curve of the beach, the women mending nets with flashing fingers, the lean-bodied youths learning the warrior’s dance on the packed sand—they were his people now. The silent, empty longhouses, where the ghosts of war canoes still seemed to rest on their rollers, were his to fill.

He had arrived from the sea like a myth, a man delivered to an island of women and boys, their own warriors lost to a war that had left Karolin defenseless. A king by default.

But as his gaze drifted from the tranquil lagoon to the hollow eyes of those empty canoe houses, a cold knot tightened in his gut. He turned his back on his new kingdom and faced the northern horizon, the wild, open water that had brought him here.

Out there, somewhere beyond the curve of the world, lay Marua. The island the natives called Palm Tree. A place as beautiful as a fever dream, and now home to nightmares made flesh.

A small voice cut through the roar of the surf. “Taori?”

He looked down. Little Tari, son of the net-maker, sat cross-legged on the coral, his dark eyes wide with a child’s unfiltered curiosity. Tari knew only that the men were gone, and then, yesterday, a strange boat had appeared out of the north. From it stepped a man sent by the sky-gods and Katafa—the girl who had been stolen by a storm years ago, returned.

“Taori,” the boy repeated, his voice small against the wind. “Who are you?”

The question struck Taori like a physical blow. Who was he? A name ghosted at the edge of his thoughts, something foreign and hard-edged. *Dick Lestrange.* It felt like a word from a forgotten language, a skin he had shed long ago. He remembered a man with a weathered face and kind eyes, Kearney, who smelled of salt and tobacco. A man who’d carved him little toy ships, so unlike the sleek canoes of the islands.

Then the memories sharpened, focused, beginning on the day the ocean gave him Katafa. She had washed ashore on Marua, a girl from Karolin, teaching him her tongue, her world, renaming him Taori. They had been alone, and it had been enough.

Until the schooner came.

He couldn't tell the boy any of this. The story was a poison he kept locked inside. He couldn’t explain the black-toothed smiles of the Melanesian crew, the reek of rum and greed, the sudden, brutal mutiny that had left the white officers dead and their ship a pillar of flame against the sky. He couldn't describe the terror of their escape in Kearney’s old dinghy, the howls of the savages fading behind them as they raced for the open sea, guided only by the faint, luminous glow in the sky that promised an island ahead. Karolin’s lagoon, reflecting the heavens.

The past was a blur of sun and storm, a life erased and rewritten by the sea. His real life began with Katafa.

He crouched, his eyes meeting the boy’s. “I am Taori,” he said, his voice softer than he intended. “Just Taori.”

Tari’s attention had already snapped elsewhere. “Look! A fish!” He scrambled to his feet and darted away toward a group of children wrestling a small, shimmering net from the shallows.

Taori stood and turned his gaze north again. The child’s question had dredged up the mud. He saw the burning ship, felt the desperate pull of the sail in his hands, heard Katafa’s ragged breathing beside him. And he saw the men they had left behind.

They had no immediate way to follow. The mutineers had burned their only deep-water vessel. But they were men, and men built things. They would build canoes. Taori knew, with a certainty that chilled him to the bone, that they would look to the horizon. They would see the same lagoon-light that had guided him here, a pale beacon in the night sky. And they would come.

It was not just his instinct as a survivor, a "savage" as the men on the schooner would have called him. It was something deeper, a shard of the man he used to be. The part of him that could think ahead, lay plans, and see the shape of a threat before it had fully formed.

That was why he’d already sent a boat for Aioma, Palia, and Tafata—three elders, too old for battle but whose hands remembered the art of shaping war canoes. It was why his eyes, scanning the tribe, had counted the youths on the cusp of manhood, nearly a hundred strong. But beneath all the strategy, pulsing like a second heart, was the raw, fierce truth: his love for Katafa. She was his other self, more precious than breath, and those men had threatened her.

They still threatened her.

A hand fell on his shoulder, warm and firm. He turned. Katafa stood beside him, her dark hair escaping its vine circlet, streaming back in the wind like a banner. Her eyes, luminous and deep, weren't on him. They were fixed on the northern horizon, the same point that held his haunted gaze.

“Look,” she whispered.

And there, as if summoned by their shared fear, it began. A subtle stain on the endless blue, a smudge in the sea-dazzle. Slowly, impossibly, it sharpened. An ethereal outline sketched itself against the sky. Palm Tree. Marua. Rising from beyond the sea line, a phantom island bleeding into the blue, a trick of the light, a mirage.

They stood frozen, her hand gripping his shoulder, as the island they had fled bloomed into view—diaphanous, beautiful, and utterly menacing. The mirage showed none of the horrors it held, only the serene, lovely dream of a tropical paradise. But they saw more. They saw the beach swarming with monstrous shapes from their nightmares. They heard the rum-crazed screams. They felt the heat of the burning ship on their faces.

The beautiful, terrible vision hung in the air, a warning and a promise. *We are here. We will come.*

As Taori stared at the mirage, a cold fire ignited in his veins. They had threatened him, that was one thing. But they had threatened Katafa. They had put fear in her eyes. That was everything. For that, there was no forgiveness.

He knew what those men were. Men without women. They would scan the sea for a prize, for a place to raid, and the sky-mirror of Karolin’s lagoon would be their map.

Then, as quickly as it had appeared, the vision wavered, dissolved, and vanished like a light blown out. The horizon was empty again, just sea and sky.

As they turned from the outer reef back toward the calm of the lagoon, Katafa pointed. A single canoe was slicing across the turquoise water, heading for them from the southern shore.

It was the canoe he had sent for. The canoe carrying the builders.

Leaving the sharp coral behind, they walked down onto the soft, white sand of the inner beach, moving together to meet the future that was coming for them.

### **Chapter 1: The Ghost on the Horizon**

The thunder of the outer reef was a constant roar at his back, a wild beast pacing the edge of the world. Salt spray, whipped to a mist by the wind, clung to his skin. But before him, the lagoon of Karolin was a mirror of impossible blue, placid and infinite.

This was his. All of it.

He’d only washed ashore yesterday, a ghost from the sea, but already the island had claimed him. The sweep of the white-sand beach, the thatched roofs of the village nestled among the palms, the sleek canoes drawn up like sleeping fish—they were his. The people—women with hibiscus in their hair, laughing children chasing crabs, wiry youths honing their fishing spears—were his to protect.

His gaze drifted from the tranquil lagoon to the long, empty houses that once sheltered war canoes. A knot tightened in his gut. He turned, his back to his new home, and stared north across the churning, open ocean.

Out there, fifty miles beyond the curve of the earth, lay Palm Tree. An island that haunted his dreams, beautiful and venomous. An island swarming with monsters.

A small voice piped up beside him. “Taori?”

He looked down. Little Tari, son of the net-maker, sat cross-legged on the coral, his dark eyes wide with a child’s fearless curiosity. Tari knew only that the island’s warriors were gone, swept away in a distant conflict, leaving them defenseless. Then yesterday, a strange man had arrived in a battered boat with Katafa—a girl the island had long thought lost to the sea. The elders were calling him a gift from the gods.

Tari, caring little for gods, pointed a small, grubby finger at him. “Who are you?”

The question echoed in a hollow space inside him. What could he say? *My name is Dick Lestrange. I was a boy, even smaller than you, when I was marooned on that northern island with an old sailor. He taught me the ways of the sea before he died. Then Katafa came, blown in by a storm, and she became my world. She taught me your tongue and gave me a new name. We were happy. Until the ship came.*

The memories were a searing flash: the glint of machetes, the reek of burning copra and spilled rum, the screams of the white crew as the Melanesian laborers they had brought turned on them. Fire clawing at the sky.

He couldn't tell the boy any of this. The name ‘Dick’ was a forgotten word from a forgotten language. The sailor, Kearney, was a fading ghost, kept alive only by the memory of the small, intricate toy boats he’d carved for him. For this new man, Taori, life had truly begun the day he met Katafa.

He knelt, meeting the child’s gaze. “I am Taori,” he said, his voice raspy. “Why do you ask, little brother?”

“I don’t know,” Tari chirped, his attention already snagged by a shriek of excitement from the beach. “Ai, a big fish!” He scrambled to his feet and scampered away toward a group of children wrestling a net from the surf.

Dick rose, his eyes drawn north again. The child's question had dredged up the mud. He saw the mutineers on Palm Tree’s beach, their bodies slick with sweat and rage. He felt the bucking of the dinghy as he and Katafa fled into the storm, the island burning behind them. He remembered landing here, yesterday, stumbling onto the sand as the women and children of Karolin surrounded them, their faces a mixture of awe and desperation. They saw a leader. He saw a man running for his life.

The men on Palm Tree had no deep-water canoes. Not yet. But they were builders. And one clear night, they would see the faint, luminous glow in the southern sky—the reflection of Karolin’s vast lagoon. A beacon. A promise.

They would come.

It wasn't just the foresight Kearney had hammered into him. It was a savage instinct, primal and certain. And beneath it all, fueling his fear and forging it into a weapon, was his love for Katafa. She was the other half of his soul, and the thought of those men touching her was an agony that eclipsed everything else.

That was why he’d sent a canoe at dawn to the southern shore to fetch the three old men—Aioma, Palia, and Tafata. They were too ancient for battle, but their hands remembered the art of carving war canoes from the giant tamanu trees.

A hand settled on his shoulder, warm and firm. He turned. It was Katafa. A strand of her dark hair had escaped its vine-lashing and whipped back in the breeze like a warrior’s plume. Her eyes, deep and knowing, were not on him, but fixed on the exact point he had been staring at.

“Look,” she breathed.

A stain appeared on the horizon. A smudge against the blinding dazzle of the sea. Slowly, impossibly, it sharpened. Lines formed, solidified. As if sketched by an invisible hand, Palm Tree bloomed into view—a phantom island, shimmering and ethereal in the heat, yet terrifyingly real.

It was a mirage, a trick of the light, but to them, it was a portent. A ghost rising from its watery grave to watch them.

They stood frozen, her hand gripping his shoulder, their minds thrown back to the nightmare. They saw the horde on the beach, heard the phantom echo of their drunken yells. That beautiful, deadly island was a painting of paradise, hiding the demons within.

As Dick stared at the mirage, a cold fire ignited in his chest. Hate, pure and clean. They had threatened him, but that was dust in the wind. They had threatened Katafa. They *still* threatened her.

The logic was brutal and simple. Those men had no women. Here, there were women. The same instinct that drew him to Katafa would draw them across the sea. The lagoon light was a map leading them straight to her.

The vision of Palm Tree flickered, wavered, and then vanished as if the sea had swallowed it whole.

As they turned from the empty ocean back toward the calm of the lagoon, Katafa pointed. A single canoe was slicing across the turquoise water, heading for them from the southern beach.

The builders were coming.

Leaving the jagged coral of the reef, they walked down onto the soft, white sand of the inner beach to meet them, two figures silhouetted against the morning sun, ready to build for war.
